name: Pikku-Finlandia
subtitle: World-leading Design for Disassembly - 2,700 m² relocatable timber pavilion with comprehensive LCA
data_source: Aalto University thesis (Hirvonen & Torvinen 2021) + Puuinfo + Helsinki City

executive_summary.headline: World's most comprehensively documented DfD building: 95 pine columns, 100% structural demountability, full EN 15978 LCA with relocation scenario modeling
key_achievements: 95 whole pine stem columns with bolted connections
Full LCA per EN 15978 with 60-year lifecycle scenarios
Relocation transport adds only 2.5% per move to lifecycle CO2
Complete academic documentation via dual Aalto theses
Steel pile foundation enables site-independent relocation
Modules up to 18 tonnes designed for crane lifting
executive_summary.why_flagship: Pikku-Finlandia represents the most comprehensively documented Design for Disassembly project globally, with full EN 15978 LCA data, scenario analysis for multiple relocations, and academic codification of Reversible Building Design principles. The 2026 relocation will provide unprecedented real-world validation.
executive_summary.why_tier: Completeness score 85/100 (Grade A). Full academic LCA documentation from Aalto University with lifecycle breakdown, relocation impact analysis, and detailed DfD methodology. Only Finland verified project but exceptionally well-documented.

budget.note: Higher initial cost justified by multiple-use lifecycle

principles.name: Visible solutions
principles.description: Non-hidden connections - all joints accessible and visible for inspection and disassembly
principles.implementation: Bolted steel connectors exposed at column bases and beam joints

principles.name: Separate systems
principles.description: Layered building systems - structure, envelope, services independently accessible
principles.implementation: MEP systems routed through accessible channels, separate from structure

principles.name: Dismountability
principles.description: Reversible fasteners - no welding, no adhesives on structural connections
principles.implementation: All structural connections bolted or screwed for multiple assembly cycles

rbd_principles.proposed_terminology: Rewindable Building Design - suggested by Torvinen as alternative to 'reversible'

foundation.advantage: No permanent ground works - enables relocation without site restoration
foundation.extraction_method: Piles can be extracted and reused or recycled

overview.circularity_strategy: Design for Disassembly - all elements designed for reuse

key_insights: DfD timber buildings are technically and economically viable

Steel pile foundations enable site-independent relocation
Bolted connections perform well over multiple assembly cycles

connections: Use bolted or screwed connections exclusively for structure
Avoid adhesives and welding on demountable elements
Select higher-quality hardware for multiple use cycles
Make all connections visible and accessible
documentation: Document all connection types and torque specifications
Include lifting points and crane access in design
logistics: Design module sizes for standard transport permits where possible
Plan crane access at both origin and destination sites
Coordinate with authorities on oversized transport routes

narrative.driver: Helsinki City needed temporary event venue while Finlandia Hall was under renovation. Instead of demolishing after temporary use, pioneering approach: design building to be relocated.
narrative.approach: Full Design for Disassembly with bolted connections, modular timber elements (CLT, LVL, glulam), steel pile foundation, and 95 signature whole-pine columns. Comprehensive academic documentation through dual Aalto theses provides LCA and methodology.
narrative.significance: World's most comprehensively documented DfD building. Proves concept that temporary buildings can have multiple lives. Codifies Reversible Building Design principles for industry adoption.
narrative.legacy: 2026 relocation to Medialukio will be first full-scale validation of timber DfD. Success will provide template for relocatable public buildings globally. Academic documentation ensures knowledge transfer to industry.
